answers.author: John Duffy
answers.text:
I've seen the calculation done both ways.  When developed and non-developed acres are combined it is typically noted as such via a footnote.   Many communities value undeveloped park land for its open space qualities/benefits and wildlife habitat so I believe that there are some legitimate reasons for including undeveloped land within the calculation.  I guess it boils down to what are you attempting to measure and then developing a sound basis for the analysis.  It might mean that your analysis contains both calculations because developed and undeveloped park lands would, I assume, have different capital and operating costs as well as different user groups.  Thus So, my apologies for no definitive answer; good luck.  John

I concur with John.  However, if you are comparing yourself to other jurisdictions, make sure that you understand what they are including.  ICMA's Center for Performance Measurement reports both separately (I don't think water acreage is separated out) and also together.
